moves.1. d4: So this was the first game of the season in the Shropshire League for Oswestry A.
moves.1... Nf6: Thankfully we won 5-0 to go top of the league!
moves.2... g6: I am hoping to play a Grünfeld Defence.
moves.3... Bg7: So I calmly complete the fianchetto.
moves.4. Bg2: As does he. I was tempted to castle and go into King's Indian type positions, but I decided instead on what I always call the Semi-Grünfeld, because that is what Max Euwe calls it in his book, "The Road to Chess Mastery", although no one else seems to call it that! He seems to be "threatening" e2-e4 now, so I play the usual Grünfeld move.
moves.5. Nf3: He plays this, rather than the more combatative cxd5.
moves.6... c6: I support my pawn on d5 and also with a threat.
moves.8... b5: I support my pawn on c4
moves.9... Nd5: Hoping that he will exchange on d5 and I can take back with the pawn and straighten out my pawns.
moves.10. Ne4: But he centralised his knight. Aleksic, Nenad (2435) vs. Dinic, Dragan (2270)		1995 continued with a4.
moves.11. e6: He sacrifices another pawn to break up my pawns.
moves.11... fxe6: So I thought I may as well take.
moves.12. Nfg5: Attacking e6, threatening a fork of my queen and rook.
moves.12... Nd7b6: So this protects it with my bishop.
moves.14... e5: I am two pawns up. I am planning on giving up the exhange for a pawn, leaving me with three pawns for the exchange and an overwhelming position.
moves.15... exd4: I leave my rook en prise, and take an important central pawn.
moves.17... Rxf8: And so do I. So for the sake of a small amount of material (rook for knight & pawn), I have established a huge centre, all my pieces are on good squares, his most attcaking pieces have been exchanged or driven back. In short black now has a massive advantage.
moves.18. Ng5: He decides to re-centralise his knight.
moves.18... d3: Opening up the long diagonal, making it hard for him to develop his Bc1, and also pushing my passed pawn nearer to the queening square.
moves.19. Qg4: He tries something on the king side, but he just doesn't have the central control or the development to do anything successfully.
moves.19... Rf5: Stopping his knight from coming in on e6.
moves.21. Ne4: Knight hits the queen. He seems to think he is winning a pawn, but I had seen all this, and he is sleep walking into a trap.
moves.22. Bxh6: This is what he had planned, but it is a massive mistake, throwing away a piece.
moves.22... Rh5: Because I have this, and his queen has no squares.
moves.23. Ng5: His only hope is this counter-attack.
moves.23... Rxh4: After a lot of thought I decided to take the queens off. I have many other winning moves, but I decided this was the simplest, transposing into an easily winning endgame.
moves.24... Rxh6: I take his bishop. I now have knight, bishop and two pawns for the rook, but what is more, my pieces and pawns are in a dominating position.
moves.25... g5: Again, there are various ways to win. This seemed the best, if he takes on g5 it means that his knight can't get back to help stop the black pawns, and 26....c3 or 26.....Bxb2 both win very easily.
moves.27. Rbc1: Trying to hold back my pawns.
moves.27... Re6: Centralising my rook, and preparing to penetrate on e2.
moves.28. Rce1: He prevents that, but allows another exchange.
moves.29... Na4: And now, his position hopeless, he resigns. Many thanks for reading. Please leave a comment or two, and rate the annotation on the star system, to let me know how I am doing. Until next time dear reader!
